surveyResults.justification: After those late shifts at work, I need somewhere quiet to decompress that's not just my flat. Plus I'm always watching shows about climate stuff on Netflix - would be nice to actually do something good for the environment instead of just binge-watching documentaries about how we're all doomed.

I'm already paying for PureGym membership but it's always packed, especially after work when I finish my shift at the shop. Having something right here in the neighbourhood would be brilliant - I could actually get a proper workout in without fighting for equipment or dealing with the commute to the gym.

I'm always knackered after long days running cables and doing installations, and I reckon getting my hands dirty with some proper gardening would be a good way to unwind. Plus, I'm getting tired of paying London prices for decent veg at the shops - growing my own tomatoes and herbs would save me a few quid and taste better than the plastic stuff from Tesco.

I've been gardening in containers on my balcony for years, and it's honestly quite limiting. As a retired GP, I've seen firsthand how many of my patients struggled with poor diets and lack of fresh veg - partly because everything's so expensive in the shops round here. Having proper growing space where neighbors could learn from each other and grow their own food would be brilliant. Plus, I'd finally have room for those tomato varieties I keep reading about but can never fit in my tiny pots.

I've been getting proper into cooking lately and the prices at the local markets are getting ridiculous. Plus I was chatting to this bloke at the community fair last month who grows his own veg - said it saves him loads and tastes miles better than supermarket stuff. Would be brilliant to have somewhere local to try my hand at it rather than just reading about it online.

Been trying to grow my own veg in the tiny back garden but it's a right mess - clay soil and barely gets any sun. Having proper plots with decent soil would be brilliant, plus I'm always fixing things for people anyway so I'd probably end up helping sort the sheds and water systems. Much more useful than some fancy sculpture nobody asked for.

I'm around kids all day at school and see how much they need safe outdoor spaces to burn off energy and just be kids. Plus, when I'm walking through the park to decompress after overwhelming days, I always notice how packed the existing playground is - there's clearly not enough play areas for all the families in the neighborhood.

I've been volunteering with the local gardening group and honestly, we desperately need more green space around here. Plus with all the air quality data I've been analyzing for work, I know how much difference trees actually make in urban areas - and it's not just the CO2 absorption, it's the particulate matter filtering that really matters day-to-day. My flat overlooks a concrete wasteland right now and it's depressing as hell.

I've been getting proper into cooking lately and posting loads of food content on my Insta - having fresh herbs and veg to grow myself would be sick for my posts. Plus my mum's always moaning about how expensive groceries are when we go shopping, so growing our own stuff would actually help out at home.

I'm around kids all the time and honestly, they need more places to just be kids and run around. Plus, whenever I'm rewatching Avatar or reading Percy Jackson, I'm always thinking about how important it is for young people to have spaces where they can imagine and create their own adventures - a good playground basically becomes whatever world they want it to be.

I'm already tracking nutrition and trying to get the kids at school more interested in where their food comes from - having a proper space to grow veg would be brilliant. Plus I'm constantly reading about sustainable living and this would actually let me practice what I preach instead of just lurking in those online communities.

After those brutal 12-hour shifts at the hospital, I'm knackered but still need to move my body - and the gym memberships round here are mental expensive. Plus when I'm jogging through Hackney Downs, I always see people queuing for the outdoor equipment. We'd actually use this, unlike half the "community art" nonsense that gets proposed and then ignored.

I've been getting more into fitness lately and the local gym is packed most evenings. Having something right in the neighborhood would be perfect for quick workouts between gaming sessions, plus I could actually stick to a routine instead of making excuses about the commute.

I go to the park with my friends after school loads, but the one near us is proper boring and the swings are always broken. It would be brilliant to have a nice new playground right here where I could play with everyone from our street and maybe even have my birthday party there!

I'm always at the local markets buying fresh veg anyway, and half my students complain they've never seen where food actually comes from. Would be brilliant to have somewhere local to grow our own - plus I could finally stop lugging heavy bags back from the market every weekend.

After thirty years of teaching, I know how much kids learn when they can get their hands dirty and watch things grow. Plus, I've been wanting to try growing my own vegetables since I retired - beats paying those supermarket prices, and I'd love having a quiet spot to read outside when the weather's nice.

I'm always trying new recipes from the Bon Appétit channel and spending a fortune on organic veg at the shops. Having my own plot would mean I could grow proper tomatoes and herbs right here in Dalston - plus I'd finally have somewhere to practice all those sustainability tips I've been picking up at the local workshops.

After being on my feet all day doing electrical work, my back and shoulders are always killing me. Having proper equipment nearby to stretch and strengthen up would be brilliant - beats driving across town to the expensive gym I can barely afford. Plus I could actually use it regularly instead of making excuses.

I've been growing vegetables in containers on my balcony since I retired, but I'm running out of space and the tomatoes never get enough sun. Having proper plots where I could grow more variety would be brilliant - plus I miss having my hands in proper soil instead of these tiny pots. Would be lovely to chat with other gardeners too, reminds me of the staff room but with better topics than marking schemes!

I'm always banging on about sustainability at the café, and honestly, I spend a fortune on groceries after work. Having a proper spot to grow some veg would be brilliant - I could finally put my money where my mouth is instead of just lecturing customers about food miles while serving them imported avocados.

I'm always buying loads of groceries and trying to plan meals properly - having my own plot to grow vegetables would cut down my shopping trips and I'd know exactly what's going into my food. Plus with all the wiring work I do, I could set up proper irrigation systems and lighting if needed.

I see kids on my street with nowhere proper to play - they end up kicking balls against walls or messing about in the road. Plus on site, I'm always having to tell kids to stay away from dangerous areas because there's nothing safe for them nearby. A playground would actually get used every day and keep the little ones out of trouble.

I'm always picking up fresh veg and herbs for my cooking experiments, and the prices at the shops round here are mental. Plus, I spend half my day tidying up other people's messes - would be lovely to have a little plot where I can grow my own tomatoes and actually see something flourish instead of just cleaning up after everyone else.

I'm constantly stuck indoors cramming for A-levels or gaming, and honestly the air quality round here is pretty grim. Having somewhere green to actually breathe and maybe get some decent shots for my media portfolio would be brilliant. Plus I've been reading about how urban forests help with climate stuff, and after doing my coursework on environmental documentaries, I'm proper convinced we need more of this.

I've been pestering the council about getting proper growing space for ages - my little window boxes just aren't cutting it anymore, and half the folks in my knitting group are always moaning about the price of vegetables. Plus, I helped organize that community garden fundraiser last spring and saw how much people want somewhere to grow their own bits and pieces.

Honestly, after staring at screens all day coding, I need something green to look at when I step outside. Plus the air quality around here is pretty grim - walked past a construction site yesterday and couldn't breathe properly for an hour. Trees would actually make a difference, and I wouldn't have to maintain anything like I would with allotments.

I keep saying I'll go to the gym after my shifts but honestly, after a 12-hour night at the hospital, the last thing I want is to trek across London to some crowded fitness place. Having something right here in Dalston would actually make me use it - especially on those days off when I'm too wired to sleep properly but too tired for anything complicated.

I've been growing herbs and veg on my tiny balcony for ages and it's honestly not enough space. Plus, half the people I chat with at the local market are always moaning about wanting somewhere proper to grow their own food. I see how these projects bring neighborhoods together when I'm working on community housing schemes - people actually talk to each other over the fence posts.

I've got my little patch at the back of the house where I grow herbs and a few veg, and it's one of the things that keeps me going since I retired. More growing space would be brilliant - and knowing my neighbors, half of them probably don't know a courgette from a cucumber. Could teach them a thing or two about proper soil preparation.

I've been growing vegetables in containers on my balcony for years, but there's only so much you can do with tomatoes in pots. Having proper soil to work with and space for a decent herb garden would be brilliant - plus I could finally try growing those prize marrows I keep reading about in my gardening magazine.

I've been growing veg in containers on my balcony for years now and it's getting cramped. Been wanting proper soil to work with and space for a decent greenhouse. Plus I could finally grow those heritage tomatoes I've been reading about in my gardening mag - need way more room than what I've got at home.

Honestly, living in London and spending most of my time either in lectures or at the café, I'm desperate for a proper green space nearby. My flat's tiny and I can't even keep plants alive on my windowsill, but when I walk through Hampstead Heath between shifts it just clears my head completely. Plus I'm always scrolling through those mental health awareness TikToks about how nature helps with stress, and with uni deadlines constantly looming, we could all use somewhere quiet to actually breathe that isn't just another concrete courtyard.

Mate, I'm out doing deliveries all day and parking around Dalston is an absolute nightmare. Half the time I'm double-parked or blocking someone's drive just to drop off a parcel. Having proper parking spaces right in the neighborhood would make my job so much easier, and honestly, everyone's always moaning about having nowhere to park their cars anyway.

Been growing my own veg in the back garden since I retired - there's nothing like fresh tomatoes you've grown yourself. Plus, with all the lads from the building site constantly moaning about grocery prices down at the pub, this would actually save people proper money. I'd volunteer to help set up the raised beds too - got all the tools and know-how from years of groundwork.

Been growing my own veg in the back garden for years now, and there's loads of folks round here who'd love the space but are stuck in flats. Plus, after decades of fixing people's kitchen sinks, I know how much money gets wasted on shop-bought produce that goes off in the fridge. Give people a proper plot and they'll actually use what they grow.

I run those charity football matches for the youth programs, and there's nowhere decent for the kids around here to play safely. Half the lads I coach have to travel miles just to find a proper pitch or even swings. We need somewhere local where families can actually let their kids be kids without worrying about traffic or dodgy areas.

I see so many families come through the supermarket with their kids going mental because there's nowhere decent for them to burn off energy around here. Plus when I'm organizing family dinners, half the conversation is about finding somewhere safe for the little ones to play that isn't miles away.

Been thinking loads about sustainability for my renewable energy project, and having local food production right here would be mental. Plus I'm always spending way too much on groceries as a student - would be brilliant to actually grow some of my own veg instead of living off meal deals from Tesco.

I'm always spending a fortune on fresh veg at the shops, and after that Brighton trip where we stayed at that B&B with the amazing garden, I've been dying to try growing my own stuff. Plus with all the dance training I do, I reckon the physical work would be brilliant cross-training, and I could finally put all those gardening shows I've been binge-watching to good use.

I'm always spending a fortune at the grocery shops on Kingsland Road, and half the veg looks like it's been sitting there for days. Having my own plot would be brilliant - I could grow the herbs and tomatoes I'm constantly buying for my cooking, plus it'd be nice to have somewhere outdoors to go that's not just waiting for the 149 bus.

Been thinking about growing my own veg for ages - all those podcasts about self-improvement keep going on about it. Plus with my grocery bill hitting £300 a month, growing some of my own food would actually save me proper money. And honestly, after being on job sites all day dealing with dodgy wiring and stressed-out customers, I could use somewhere quiet to just dig around in the dirt and switch off.

Mate, I walk through Dalston all the time and there's barely anywhere decent for kids to play - just seen too many families having to trek miles just to find a proper playground. Plus when I'm cramming for exams, bit of background laughter from kids playing is actually quite nice, beats the constant traffic noise we get round here.

I'm always sourcing fresh herbs and veg for the café menu, and the prices keep going up. Having local allotments would mean fresher ingredients right on our doorstep, plus I reckon half my regular customers would love to get their hands dirty growing their own stuff. It's practical and brings people together - I see how community projects work when we host local events at the café.

I've been gardening for decades and there's nothing like growing your own veg. Half the folks round here don't even have proper gardens, just tiny yards or nothing at all. I see people at the market paying silly money for tomatoes I could grow for pennies. Plus I'd love to pass on what I know about soil preparation and companion planting to some of the younger families - been wanting to do more of that since I retired.

I see so many patients at the surgery complaining about the cost of fresh veg, and I'd love to have a proper space to grow my own tomatoes and herbs. Plus, it'd give me something to do with my hands when I'm not knitting - been wanting to try gardening properly since I moved to Dalston.

I've been getting into cooking more lately - trying to keep my grocery bills down with all these price rises - and having fresh veg right on my doorstep would be brilliant. Plus I've been watching loads of gardening videos on YouTube during my lunch breaks at work, and I reckon I could actually give it a proper go. Much more useful than another sculpture nobody will look at twice.

I'm always popping round to Borough Market for decent fabric, and the prices there make me think about how much we're all spending on food. Plus, I'd love somewhere to grow my own cotton plants - been wanting to try that for ages, from seed to finished fabric. Would be brilliant to have fresh veg right on the doorstep too, especially with how mental the grocery bills have gotten lately.

I've been trying to grow my own veg in little pots on my windowsill but it's proper cramped in my flat. Would be amazing to actually have space to grow proper food - I spend ages researching vegan recipes online but half the ingredients cost a fortune at the shops. Plus I'm always stressed from uni deadlines and I reckon getting my hands dirty in the soil would be way better for my mental health than scrolling through articles about climate change all evening.

I'm already going to the regular gym twice a week but it's getting expensive, and mum's always moaning about the membership fees. Having proper outdoor equipment right here would be brilliant - I could work out more often without the cost, and it'd be way more convenient than trekking to the gym after school.

Been tending my little back garden for years now and there's nothing like growing your own veg. Half the folks round here live in flats with no proper outdoor space - they'd love a patch to call their own. Plus I could finally grow proper tomatoes instead of cramming them into pots by my kitchen window.

I've been wanting to grow my own veg for ages but my flat's got no proper outdoor space. Plus with food prices going mental and me donating to the food bank every quarter, it'd be brilliant to actually help grow stuff for the community too. My cat would probably love prowling around the plots as well.

My kid's always dragging me to the overcrowded playground in London Fields - would be brilliant to have something local where I don't have to battle for swings and can actually keep an eye on them while I'm on work calls. Plus I see how much energy they burn off there, which means easier bedtimes for me.

I spend way too many hours staring at screens for work, and honestly the concrete jungle vibe around here gets overwhelming. Having some proper green space where I can actually decompress after those late coding sessions would be amazing - plus it'd be nice to have somewhere quiet to take calls when I'm working from home and my flatmate's being loud.

After doing those brutal night shifts, I really need somewhere quiet to decompress before heading home. The green space would be perfect for my post-shift walks - much better than wandering around concrete trying to clear my head. Plus, I keep seeing patients with respiratory issues and stress-related conditions, and having more trees in the area could actually help with air quality and give people a proper place to unwind.

I've got herbs and flowers in my back garden already, and half my neighbors are always asking about growing their own veg but haven't got the space. Plus, I see the waiting lists for allotments at the council - they're mental. We could actually sort something out ourselves instead of waiting years for a proper plot somewhere else.

Half my patients come in with diabetes and hypertension - proper food access is a massive issue round here. I've seen what growing your own veg does for people's health, both physically and mentally. Plus my neighbor's been going on about wanting to grow proper tomatoes for years, and frankly, anything that gets people outdoors and active beats another bloody car park.

I've been trying to grow veg on my tiny balcony for ages and it's just not cutting it - barely got three tomatoes last summer. Been wanting proper soil and space to actually experiment with companion planting and maybe try some of those heritage varieties I keep reading about. Plus I spend way too much on organic veg at the market, so this could actually save me some cash.

Got two little ones myself and the nearest decent playground is a proper trek from here. Been taking them to that tatty one by the estate but half the equipment's broken and there's always broken glass about. Would be brilliant having something safe and close where the kids can actually play without me worrying about them getting hurt.

My back's killing me from all the night shift cleaning work - bending over, lifting, pushing heavy equipment around. An outdoor gym right nearby would be perfect for me to get some proper exercise during the day when I'm not sleeping. Better than paying for a gym membership I can barely afford, and I could fit it in between getting home from work and having my kip.

I'm constantly stressed from juggling college work and my freelance photography gigs, and that mindfulness workshop I went to last month really opened my eyes to how much green spaces help with mental health. Plus I could get some amazing nature shots for my portfolio right on our doorstep instead of trekking across London with my camera gear.

Been hitting up those gaming lounges way too much lately and could use somewhere chill to read outdoors. Plus when I'm helping my little cousin with math homework, it'd be nice to have a quiet green spot nearby instead of always being stuck inside.

I've been gardening on my tiny balcony for years and it's driving me mad - there's barely room for a proper tomato plant. An allotment would give me space to grow proper vegetables like I used to help my mum with when I was little, and I could finally try all those heritage varieties I keep seeing on Monty Don's show.

I'm already paying for a gym membership but half the time I can't get there because of my late shifts at the hospital. Having something right here in Dalston would be brilliant - I could actually squeeze in a proper workout between getting home and crashing out, instead of ordering another Uber Eats because I'm too knackered to do anything else.

I've been getting more into cooking lately - been watching loads of Tasting History with Max Miller and trying out recipes. Having fresh herbs and vegetables right nearby would be brilliant for my kitchen experiments, plus I could use the gardening time to decompress after those heavy lesson planning sessions. Been feeling pretty burnt out recently and getting my hands in the soil sounds like exactly what I need.

I'm always picking up fresh veg at the shops for my cooking experiments, and the prices are getting ridiculous. Plus, I see so many of my patients dealing with diet-related health issues - having a proper community garden where people can grow their own food and actually know where it comes from would be brilliant. I'd love to finally have space to grow proper herbs for my baking too.

Been growing tomatoes and herbs on my balcony for years now, but proper soil would make all the difference. Plus from my volunteer work at the food bank, I see how many families could really use fresh veg they can grow themselves - saves money and tastes better than what you get in the shops.

I'm always telling people at work about growing their own herbs - nothing beats fresh basil or thyme in your cooking. Plus I've been wanting to expand beyond the little herb garden starter kit I got, and having proper allotment space would let me grow enough to actually preserve and store for the winter months. Would save me a fortune at Borough Market too.

I'm always posting about my cooking experiments and budget meals on Instagram, but having to buy everything from Tesco is killing my food budget. Growing my own veg would be perfect for my food photography content too - imagine the farm-to-table shots I could get. Plus I've been watching loads of those Bon Appétit videos about seasonal cooking and I'm proper curious to try growing some of the ingredients myself.

I walk past the same boring route to school every day and there's literally nowhere decent for kids to hang out around here. Plus at work I see so many families come in with restless kids who've clearly been cooped up - having somewhere proper for them to burn off energy would be mental for the whole area.

I've been working in the community kitchen garden club since I retired, and I know how much everyone loves growing their own veg. Plus with prices at the shops these days, having a bit of land to grow tomatoes and herbs would help stretch the pension. My neighbor Mrs. Rahman is always asking where she can get a proper plot - this would be perfect for folks like us.

With my night shifts, regular gyms are either closed when I'm free or packed when I need to sleep. Having outdoor equipment I can use any time would be perfect - I could get my workout in before heading to work or when I wake up in the afternoon without worrying about opening hours or crowds.

I do mild gardening twice a week already and it's become one of my favorite parts of the routine - gets me moving and I actually enjoy the process. Having proper allotment space nearby would let me expand beyond just puttering around at home, plus I'm always buying fresh produce anyway so growing some of it myself makes sense.

I've been wanting to grow my own veg for ages but my flat doesn't even have a proper balcony. Plus working at the café, I see how much we spend on fresh herbs and produce - would be brilliant to have somewhere local to grow stuff. My neighbor's always going on about how expensive everything's getting at the shops, and honestly, she's not wrong.

Got two young ones myself and there's barely anywhere safe for them to play round here. Every weekend I'm dragging them halfway across London just to find a decent playground. Be brilliant to have something right on our doorstep where I can keep an eye on them while they burn off some energy.

Been thinking about growing my own veg since I started those Thursday market trips - prices keep going up and half the tomatoes are rubbish anyway. Plus I see the same faces from the knitting club at the community center, reckon a few of us could get our hands dirty together. Beats sitting around watching Columbo reruns all afternoon.

Been watching loads of Binging with Babish lately and getting proper into cooking - would be brilliant to grow my own veg instead of paying mad prices at the shops. Plus I'm already doing DIY projects around the flat, so working with my hands in the dirt would be a nice change from dealing with wires and circuits all day.

Look, I've been doing construction and maintenance work my whole life - I know how to work with my hands and grow things. Plus with the way prices are going, especially back in Turkey, growing your own vegetables just makes sense. I've got the space in my flat but nowhere proper to plant. My mother always had a little garden when I was young, and the fresh tomatoes and peppers would save me a fortune at the shops.

I've been wanting to try growing my own herbs and vegetables after watching all those cooking shows, and with my cleaning business I'm always looking for natural alternatives to harsh chemicals. Plus I spend so much time indoors cleaning other people's houses - having a little plot to tend would be perfect for unwinding after work.

Been growing my own veg in pots on the balcony for years now, but there's only so much you can do with a few tomato plants. Had allotments when I was younger and nothing beats fresh carrots straight from the ground. Plus, at my age, the gentle exercise of gardening keeps me moving without being too hard on the joints - much better than those outdoor gym contraptions that look like they'd put me in A&E.

I've been growing tomatoes and peppers on my balcony for years, but there's only so much you can do in pots. My neighbor Ahmet and I are always talking about how we'd love proper soil to work with - especially for the aubergines that never quite work out in containers. Plus, with food prices the way they are, having fresh vegetables would help stretch the budget.

I walk past the same boring streets every day going to work and there's literally nothing for families round here. My mate Sarah's always complaining she has to drag her kid all the way to Victoria Park just for a swing. Plus at the shop I see loads of parents buying snacks and looking proper stressed trying to entertain their little ones - would be nice if they had somewhere local to go.

I've been trying to get the kids at school interested in growing stuff - we did a small vegetable patch project last term and they were actually engaged for once. Plus with food prices these days, growing my own veg would help the budget, and I'm already watching cooking videos on YouTube so might as well grow the ingredients too.

I've been growing herbs and flowers on my tiny balcony for ages, but I'm constantly running out of space. Having proper allotments would mean I could actually grow vegetables and have room for composting - plus I see so many patients at the hospital who'd benefit from getting their hands dirty and having fresh air instead of being cooped up indoors all the time.

I'm constantly stressed from uni work and the city noise, and I've found that walking through green spaces really helps when I'm writing songs or need to clear my head. Plus when I'm studying for my Political Science essays, I could actually use a quiet outdoor spot that's not just another concrete courtyard in Dalston.

I'm always listening to podcasts about environmental stuff on my walks to school, and honestly Dalston could use more green space. Plus when I'm walking back from the gym in the evenings, it'd be nice to have somewhere quiet to sit that isn't just concrete everywhere. My friends and I are always complaining there's nowhere decent to hang out outdoors around here.

There's literally nowhere decent for kids to hang out around here - the only playground nearby has broken swings and rubbish everywhere. Plus I'm always seeing little kids from our building having to play in the car park, which is proper dangerous. At least with a playground I could actually use it too, and maybe bring my art supplies to draw there when the weather's nice.

I've been trying to expand my gardening beyond the few pots on my windowsill, and the community forums are always buzzing about people wanting growing space. Plus, I reckon it'd bring folks together - I've seen how the bird feeding down at Hackney Downs gets people chatting. Proper soil to work with would be brilliant.

I'm proper into cooking and always looking for ways to save money on groceries - spending £4 on herbs at Tesco when I could just grow my own is mad. Plus I've been wanting to try growing my own veg for my YouTube cooking videos, and having a little plot right here in Dalston would be perfect. Way more practical than a sculpture park or whatever.

I've been watching these cooking channels on YouTube constantly and keep wanting to try growing my own herbs and vegetables, but my flat doesn't have any proper outdoor space. Plus with how much I spend at the local markets for decent produce, having a little plot where I could actually grow some of the ingredients I see in those recipes would be brilliant.

I'm always buying veg from the Dalston Wholefood Market, and it's getting pricey. Would love to grow my own tomatoes and herbs - plus I reckon a lot of the lads from the pub would be well up for it. Could use my hands for something other than fixing pipes for once.

I'm already in the local gardening group and we're always moaning about the waiting list for proper allotments - this would be brilliant for us lot and I could finally grow my own veg instead of paying supermarket prices. Plus I see how stressed customers get at work when they're shopping, so having somewhere peaceful to dig about would be perfect.

Been growing my own veg for years and there's loads of folks round here who'd love a proper plot but don't have the garden space. Plus with the way grocery prices are going, growing your own spuds and tomatoes makes real sense - I've saved a fair bit on my weekly shop just from what I grow at home.

Mate, I'm on my bike 8+ hours a day doing deliveries - my legs are solid but my upper body's knackered. There's nowhere decent to work out round here that doesn't cost a fortune. Plus when I'm waiting between deliveries in the area, I could actually use it instead of just sitting around scrolling my phone.

I'm always meal prepping those quick stir-fries and pasta dishes, but the veg from Tesco is proper expensive and half-dead by the time I get it home. Would be brilliant to grow my own tomatoes, herbs, bit of lettuce - save money and actually know where my food's coming from. Plus I'm getting tired of takeaways every other night.

I've been wanting to try growing my own vegetables after getting into that chickpea curry recipe - would love to have fresh herbs and maybe some tomatoes right there instead of paying crazy prices at the shops. Plus I listen to enough true crime podcasts to know I need a hobby that gets me outside and away from screens for a bit.

I'm always seeing little kids around Dalston with nowhere decent to play - they end up kicking footballs against walls or hanging around the shops looking bored. Plus when I'm walking back from swimming practice, I see parents trying to entertain their kids in that tiny patch by the bus stop. A proper playground would actually get used every day.

I'm always drawing kids playing and having adventures in my art, and when I walk around Dalston I notice there aren't many proper play spaces where families can hang out. Plus, I love watching how creative kids get when they have good playground equipment - gives me tons of inspiration for my cartoon characters and stories.

I've been growing vegetables on my windowsill for years and it's such a pain - barely enough space for a few herbs. Having proper allotments would mean I could finally grow the tomatoes and courgettes I'm always buying at the market, plus it'd give me and the other retirees something productive to do together. Much better than another bit of concrete or some fancy art nobody asked for.

I'm proper into cooking shows like Tasty and Bon Appétit on YouTube, always watching them after my shifts, and I've been wanting to try growing my own veg for ages. Plus with how much I spend on groceries working at the supermarket - seeing those prices go up every week - having my own little plot would actually save me some money and give me something to do that's not just watching telly.

Been spending way too much time indoors coding and staring at screens lately - could really use somewhere green to decompress when I'm stuck on a particularly nasty bug. Plus I've been reading about how trees actually help with air quality, and honestly the traffic fumes around here are getting ridiculous when I walk to the corner shop.

followUpResults.justification: Honestly, I'm all about having options - like how I'll binge-watch an entire season of Stranger Things on my days off but then need something quick like a single episode of The Great British Bake Off when I get home late from work. Same energy here - sometimes you want to go big with tomatoes, other times you just need a small herb patch you can actually maintain between shifts.

Working retail, I see how different customers need different things - some want just herbs for their windowsill, others are feeding a whole family. Plus at the gym I notice people work out differently based on their fitness levels. Makes sense to have options that actually fit what people can handle rather than one-size-fits-all approach.

Reminds me of electrical panel layouts - you need different sized breakers for different circuits. Same logic applies here. When I help my neighbor with his garden, the herbs do fine in small spaces but the tomatoes need room to spread. Makes sense to match the space to what you're growing rather than forcing everything into the same box.

After years of tending my little patch in Dalston, I've learned you need flexibility. I've got narrow beds for herbs by the kitchen window where I can grab them while cooking, deeper raised sections for my tomatoes and beans, and ground-level rows for the root vegetables. My dodgy knees from all those years doing house calls mean I can't be bending down everywhere, but some plants just do better at ground level. It's like treating patients - one size never fits all.

I've been experimenting with container gardening on my balcony for the past year - some herbs do brilliant in small pots while the tomatoes need way more space. Plus when I helped organize that community fair last summer, saw how different families had completely different needs for their plots. Makes sense to have flexibility rather than forcing everyone into the same setup.

Had to help my neighbor redo her whole garden setup last spring - she had these tiny raised beds that were a pain to work in, but also some ground-level stuff that got waterlogged.
